Posts.Content: Hi, I am in a similar poistion, had surgery on 12th Feb. Saw my surgeon on 2nd March. She advise me to have my tissue tested to see if chemo would be beneficial to me  My lymph nodes and tissues were clear of cancer so I don't need anymore surgery. I find out next Monday for my results. I don't know what grade or stage my cancer is at, she didn't say, but she said years ago chemo would be the next treatment for my type of cancer (wished I asked now).  Do I take the risk and not have chemo if the risks are on the borderline? Everything is a waiting game, but I suppose they know what they are doing and want to know 100% before they give out the facts. Hope your results go well. Jen x
Posts.Title: Scared about today

Posts.Content: Got a sick note from doc for my surgery for the last two weeks I had off. I have my referral next Wednesday. We were discussing my work and I said as I have got breast cancer they cannot discriminate me by law (i.e make me redundant because of it). He said I haven't got cancer anymore as I had the lump removed last week so they can. So bascially any futher treatment I may need in the future will not be class of having breast cancer unless it comes back.  I was quite put off by his remark.  He said he had to live with me and my "cancer" (wait for it...since 25th of Jan and he only had one day off from work for my surgery on 12th Feb)  so he knows what cancer is like.  Nothing really has changed for him, ok he took the dog for a walk, cleaned my guinea pig hutch, did the ironing and vacuuming (its not like he hasn't done this before the surgery).  Yes I had some pain and still am in pain, but this hasn't affected his life or the running of the household. Apart from my family and line manager I haven't mentioned it to anyone. I don't think he has told his family and non of our friends know. The only people I really talk about it is you lot on this forum.  I went to to all my other appointments on my own. My sister said she will come with me to my next one. Yes its true the lump has gone, and hoping it stays gone, but he doesn't realise the emotional aspects of it all.  He just wants me to forget it and move on, I haven't had radiotherapy yet!!  On the good side my brother (who has bowel and liver cancer) has told me you get free carpark at the hospital if you have chemo or radiotherapy yay.  Anyway rant over, its probably me being too emotional
Posts.Title: Husband remark to cancer

Posts.Content: His mother died of secondary bone cancer 11 years ago so you would thought he would be supportive. He is the sort if man who will answer question for you so if I was really ill he would say I am fine. He says he was seeing it in a positive side that it has gone. He told my youngest we are going camping in Easter. I said we are not 100% sure what treatment I need yet but he thinks a few blast of radiotherapy and all be OK. I am hoping the same, but I now I worried letting my daughter down if treatment concise with Easter. I think he is an ostrich. I'm just going to leave him to it got enough to worry about.
Posts.Title: Husband remark to cancer

Posts.Content: Well he cleaned the guinea pigs out again this morning so I think must be having another think of what he said .  Then again My ten year wanted to go into a Cancer Research shop yesterday whilst in town, but he got annoyed with her.  It is a big thing for my daughter she sees it differently to him, but he thinks I am only mentioning it and saying 'I've breast cancer' to get attention, but this is not the case at all. I am the quiet, sit in the corner type and he is the one who is more sociable. If the shoe was on the other foot it would be different case all together.  He like a Jekyll and Hyde. I am going in give Maggies a ring tomorrow.

Posts.Content: I am having my last chemo on 16th Aug, yay. How long a gap is between chemo and radiotherapy. Is it straight away or do they leave it for as few weeks. Got some appointments need booking so trying to sort out my diary.
Posts.Title: Times between chemo and radiotherapy

Posts.Content: My score was 22 so in the low side of the middle. I was diagnosed grade 3, 38mm ER+. There is a lot of cancer in my family so I wanted to give it everything I got as I my youngest daughter is only 10. My parents wanted me to try everything possible too. My BC nurse said you take a year out of your life to give the rest of your life. Got my fourth chemo today, not looking forward to it, but I got a bit of phobia about being sick. Chemo is not easy but I wanted to know I've gave it my all. Before the test was available  I would be having chemo anyway, if my family never had it I probably think differently. It all depends on your own personal circumstances. I don't think there is a right/wrong decision so don't feel guilty whatever you decide. Good luck, hope it all goes well.

Posts.Title: Job interview

Posts.Content: Hi, I think its about 6 weeks.
Posts.Title: Stitches

Posts.Content: I knew I would lose my hair when told about chemo treatment. My scalp was sore and my hair fell out in undignified clumps. Shaving the rest off was awful. My children was there so I had to make out it was OK with smiles but I was crying inside. I've got one chemo treatment left, will my hair grow back, what colour. How long will I need to wear head scarves for. My eyebrows are thinning but eyelashes, for now, are OK. My husband shaves his head in the summer but his hair grows back normal. I have a little fluff. I appreciate the reasoning of the fund raising but they make it sound that chemo is easy. The emotional impact of hair loiss, fatigue, nausea, low moods, joint pain is horrible. I don't think anyone will understand unless they been through it themselves.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: How long are people having off work? My line manager texted me this morning. No one at work know I have cancer apart from her so they all think I am off work because its half term week. I don't know what to say or what excuse to tell people. There is another girl in my dept who also has cancer and I am worried people will compare us. She had a few weeks off but seem to be a lot stronger than me but she further ahead with her treatment. I am back on codine and paracetamol as my arm is killing me. I feel like a right wimp.

Posts.Content: I suffered fatigue at beginning of the week but I also had a cold virus so it probably didn't help. Also had stomach cramps and feeling sick again not sure if its because of surgery or virus. My referral is on 2nd march and I am terrified that they are going to say it is worse than they first expected. Close family members have/had cancer so you would presume that I would be prepared but I think cancer is an individual journey which nothing can prepare for that emotional impact. I have to make an appointment with my GP next week as I need a sick note for work. It would it be nice if they signed me off work on my op day as I am worried about works response. I don't think employers realise how mentally upsetting having cancer is.  I was finding it hard to concentrate on simple tasks. The waiting game is definitely the worse.

Going to have breakfast now with my 6 tablets
Posts.Title: Temperature range

Posts.Content: The waiting is the worse part. I didn't tell anyone at first, but probably I should not gone through it alone. Just had surgery so now waiting again for results. Hopefully it all went well. My children are 17 and 10. My 10 year old can be tearful but I think it helps just to be honest. Cancer is not uncommon in my family as few members have been through it so it was not new to them even though my diagnosis was still upsetting. My brother's bowel cancer has disappeared which has amazed his doctors  so there is always hope. I try to focus on the present rather than the future as I felt it was overwhelming me and I was having anxiety. Hope your news will be positive and all goes well. Take care x
Posts.Title: Awaiting results of biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi, I am having my first chemo next Friday so I am not sure what my side effects will be or which drugs I will be taking. Do people work through chemo or do they have the whole 18 weeks off. If you do work can you take the odd day off in case you feel unwell or get an infection. I am having radiotherapy and hormone treatment after chemo so I don't know what side effects these will have. I feel like I am messing people around as I can't say what is going to happen. I already been asked about which days I am having off over the summer so I can cover for someone. My hair is long and usually in a pony tail  so its going to be bad enough having it cut short then working wearing head scarfs. Really terrified with this prospect as I don't like being centre of attention.
